awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  High thermal conductivity continuous fiber reinforced 3D printing materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop thermally conductive 3D printing materials for cooling of high-performance electronic devices.  As electronic devices become more compact and energy-dense, there is a growing challenge of overheating, resulting in poor performance and device failure. This problem is particularly relevant to transportation and energy-related technologies increasingly reliant on high-performance electronic components, such as electric motors, battery packs, power electronics, and high-performance processors.  This project will develop a new additive manufacturing composite material with thermal conductivity 1000x higher than standard plastics, enabling lightweight, corrosion-resistant, and high-performance heat transfer technologies. Moreover, the materials enable 3D printing on low-cost desktop Fused Deposition Modeling printers without significant hardware modifications, drastically reducing the complexity and cost of printing high performance components. By creating a transformational material for use on a broadly accepted additive manufacturing technology platforms, this project will help create a new market for advanced heat transfer technologies that can significantly increase the performance of electronic devices.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will result in the development of plastic composite materials with higher effective thermal conductivity than aluminum and the ability to be printed on low cost 3D printers. Thermally conductive plastic composites are traditionally composed of base polymer and a high content of thermally conductive filler particles, resulting in poor mechanical properties, high viscosity, high cost and processing difficulties (including inability to 3D print reliably), and a maximum thermal conductivity of ~30 W/m-K (nearly an order of magnitude lower than aluminum). Metals conduct heat well, but are heavy, expensive to manufacture into complex shapes, and can be susceptible to corrosion and fouling when interacting with fluids. This project is proposing a new composite system consisting of a core-shell structure with a core of continuous high thermal conductivity continuous fiber and a shell of a composite thermally conductive matrix. Utilizing 3D printing, this material can be printed into complex shapes to produce new heat transfer parts such as heat sinks, heat exchangers, liquid coldplates and other technologies with thermal performance exceeding metals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this Phase I project, TCPoly created a plastic composite 3D printer filament with heat conduction properties rivaling aluminum, so that engineers can design cost-effective high-performance plastic molds and high-performance heat transfer devices such as heat exchangers and heat sinks. Our filament is the material that goes into a 3D printer (like an ink cartridge in a traditional 2D printer). The material technology developed under the Phase I grant, which we call SolidCore, contains embedded continuous wires inside plastic 3D printing filament.  The CopperCore filament possesses 200x higher thermal conductivity compared with normal plastics, and 10x improvement compared with our previous best materials. CopperCore is the highest thermal conductivity plastic composite in the world that can be used in a normal manufacturing process. Our innovation is a proprietary thermally conductive composite matrix materials and our extrusion technique to create and print filament with continuous wire already embedded; competitors combine the filament and continuous fiber during the print process requiring the use of a more expensive printer, limiting the materials selection, and offering no compatibility with other off-the-shelf 3D printers. Our technology will allow these high-performance composites to be used on a wide range of open material printers, dramatically increasing the potential customer base. Our process is also the only one to combine high thermal conductivity continuous wires and fibers. In addition, our ThemoCore filament provides embedded heating wires to provide de-icing, mold heating, and other heating applications. TCPoly is building a low-cost platform to print composite/continuous wires and fibers for various applications through a materials centric approach that utilizes current commercially available hardware. The included image shows an example of CopperCore high thermal conductivity 3D printing filament.

During Phase I we spoke with many potential customers in a variety of industries including aerospace, automotive, and mold tooling and engaged in early development projects to test our material in applications. We are working with different companies to use ThermoCore filament to de-ice heat exchanger fins, using ThermoCore to provide heating of injection molds, and using CopperCore? for high performance heat sinks.

In addition to developing the new SolidCore 3D printing filaments, TCPoly developed hardware to adapt commercially available Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printers to print the SolidCore filaments and software to control the printing to allow for printing of continuous wires/fibers. TCPoly has achieved the Phase I technical objectives, demonstrated strong commercial interest, and is in the process of securing beta customers for larger development moving forward. This technology represents the only plastic composite on the market that can conduct heat like a metal and represents a large weight reduction (~40%).

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2021
Modified by: Thomas Bougher

Image
  • TCPoly CopperCore filament has a thermal conductivity 200 times higher than standard plastics and can be used on modified FDM 3D printers.
    TCPoly
    Public Domain
    Thomas Bougher
    TCPoly CopperCore Filament
